descriptions: Project website redesigned in September 2024 to include status, goals, deliverables, and progress, with documentation for end users, facility operators, and developers; public APIs and libraries documentation generated automatically; planned expansion for user-focused materials and community outreach; public documentation on GitHub; project listed on ETH Open Research Data Portal and indexed by European Open Science Cloud and Google dataset search.
Public project website
Subpage on the ETH ORD Data Portal

SciCat Data Catalog, open repository for data from PSI facilities, serves as primary repository for all Swiss EM datasets; integrates EMPIAR, EMDB, and PDB; supports standardized metadata collection and deposition.
Enhanced the PSI SciCat Data Catalog

Swiss EM datasets deposited in SciCat Data Catalog, supporting publication and broader reuse; enables streamlined deposition into EMPIAR, EMDB, and PDB international databases; 6.4 PB/year of data expected across sites.
Apoferritin dataset
Expected to be around 1200 datasets/year following release
SciCat backend (enhanced)
SciCat CLI (enhanced)
ETHZ Archiving Services (new)
Globus transfer library (new)
Metadata conversion tools (new)
OSCEM format converters (new)
Depositor to OneDep (new)
Ingestor to OpenEM (new)

OSC-EM metadata extractor tools for automatic extraction from supported EM software and instruments, SciCat open-source data catalog with EM/multi-facility features, S3 and Globus data transfer protocol support, multi-user ingestor service for data archiving, microservice-based archiving system for ETHZ long-term storage, converter from OSC-EM schema to PDBx/mmCIF syntax for metadata interoperability.

OSC-EM metadata standard established for EM community, including 115 unique metadata entries for 4 life science cryo-EM methods; PDBx/mmCIF standard adopted for cryoEM and cryoET applications and compatibility with EMDB; engagement with EM glossary initiative, NXem format, and international standards projects.
Founding member of the Open Standards Community for Electron Microscopy and main schema contributor
Mapping to related ontologies and schemas

Seven workshops held with related initiatives across Europe and the US on EM standards, involving entities such as EMGlossary, EMDB/PDB, Instruct-ERIC, ISPyB, NeXus-NXem, CZ Imaging Institute, PREMISE.
OSC-EM Standards Workshop at PSI, 22-23 Feb 2024. 22 in-person participants.
Planned training and educational resources (videos, training materials), newly added documentation section for end users, training and outreach lead by co-applicant; user training and outreach (WP4).
Project documentation
Training workshops are planned for 2025
1 publication anticipated in 2025
CCPEM Spring Symposium 2023. 24-26 April 2023. Poster
Agreeing community standards for cryoET data preservation and reuse: data structure, metadata, ontologies etc. 17-19 Apr 2024, EMBL-EBI, Hinxton, UK. Invited participant
CCPEM Doppio Workshop. 16-18 Jan 2024. Oxford, UK. Invited participant.
Machine actionable data for chemical sciences (MADICES) workshop. 22-25 Apr 2024, Berlin.
SciCatCon User Meeting. 2-4 Jul 2024. Presentation
New Opportunities for Better User Group Software (NOBUGS). 23-27 Sept 2024. Poster
EnhanceR Symposium 2024. 7 Nov 2024. Presentation

Dissemination through participation in workshops, documentation on GitHub, public communication, project website expansion for outreach, project listed and indexed by major data portals for visibility.
Follow ETH-ORD M2 Identity Management Guidelines
Coordinate with ETH-ORD M2 API projects
ETHZ FAIR Research Data Board
none anticipated
Initiated OSC-EM collaboration (around 30 participants, including Instruct-ERIC, Diamond Light Source, EM software developers, EMPIAR/EMDB/PDB representatives)
Collaboration with EM Glossary (Helmholtz Center Berlin)
German FAIRmat data infrastructure for development of NXem format
Alignment and integration with EBI databases (EMDB, EMPIAR, PDB)
Joint cryoET standardization efforts with CZI and EBI (CryoET Standards Working Group)
Coordination and reciprocal workshops with PREMISE project (ETH-ORD Explore)
Synergies and coordination on ORD best practices with upcoming ETH-ORD Measure 2 projects
none yet
Alpha release at UNIBAS to serve ~100 researchers; full deployment at all facilities to serve >600 researchers; estimated 500 users/year benefiting from OpenEM ORD practices.
~500 microscope users per year
Hundreds of data consumers. For comparison, EMPIAR has around 5000 downloads per year with 32'000 entries.

citation.matching_text: A major website redesign (https://swissopenem.github.io/) was released in September.
* Public project website: (https\://swissopenem.github.io/)

A major website redesign (https://swissopenem.github.io/) was released in September. Information on the project status, goals and deliverables are easily accessible and the progress of the project is documented publicly. A new documentation section has also been added, which includes documentation targeted at either end users, facility operators, or OpenEM developers. Documentation of public APIs and libraries is generated automatically as part of the continuous deployment pipeline. Additional videos and training materials are planned, and all documentation will be updated following feedback from the alpha and beta milestones.

UNIBE will expand the project website (https://swissopenem.github.io) significantly in the second phase of the project to provide user-focused materials and community outreach. OpenEM is also listed on the ETH [Open ](https://open-research-data-portal.ch/)Research Data Portal and indexed by the [European ](https://open-science-cloud.ec.europa.eu/)Open Science Cloud, [Google ](https://datasetsearch.research.google.com/)dataset search, and other portals.
* Public project website: (https\://swissopenem.github.io/)
* Subpage on the ETH ORD Data Portal (https\://open-research-data-portal.ch/projects/open-em-data-network/)
A major website redesign (https://swissopenem.github.io/) was released
Public project website: (https\://swissopenem.github.io/)
OpenEM is also listed on the ETH [Open ](https://open-research-data-portal.ch/)Research Data Portal
Subpage on the ETH ORD Data Portal (https\://open-research-data-portal.ch/projects/open-em-data-network/)
indexed by the [European ](https://open-science-cloud.ec.europa.eu/)Open Science Cloud

citation.matching_text: Central to this initiative is the SciCat Data Catalog, operated by the Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI). This catalog is already established as an open repository for data from the PSI large-scale facilities
| New or enhanced repositories and/or catalogues: | 1 | - Enhanced the PSI SciCat Data Catalog

SciCat Data Catalog, operated by the Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI). This catalog is already established as an open repository for data from the PSI large-scale facilities, enabling access to data from the synchrotron, free electron laser, and neutron source. With OpenEM this is now being established to also serve as the primary repository for all Swiss EM datasets.
- Enhanced the PSI SciCat Data Catalog

repositories_catalogues.reasoning: The SciCat Data Catalog is described consistently across pages 3 and 8 as the only reported new or enhanced repository/catalogue for this project. Page 16 is only a review - no new/enhanced output. Both description snippets are relevant and distinct. Three URLs are provided for the catalog and related resources. All data is taken verbatim, and quantity is confirmed as 1.

citation.matching_text: tools to automatically extract metadata following the OSC-EM schema. Currently, these tools cover commonly used software (SerialEM/EPU/Tomo5) and instruments (Thermo Fisher Scientific’s fleet of EM)
SciCat is an open-source data catalog used at about a dozen scientific facilities. SciCat has a mature core catalog, to which we have added features for EM and to enable multi-facility usage.
S3 and Globus data transfer protocols, a multi-user ingestor service that runs at each facility
a microservice-based archiving system that allows upload of datasets and reliable, asynchronous storage on the LTS
converter from the OSC-EM schema to PDBx/mmCIF syntax. The converter is designed to remain sustainable to future changes
https\://github.com/SciCatProject/scicat-backend-next
https\://github.com/paulscherrerinstitute/scicat-cli
https\://github.com/SwissOpenEM/ScopeMArchiver
https\://github.com/SwissOpenEM/globus-transfer-request
https\://github.com/osc-em/converter-JSON-to-mmCIF
https\://github.com/SwissOpenEM/Depositor
https\://github.com/SwissOpenEM/Ingestor

config.system_prompt:
EXTRACTION STRATEGY:
  1. PRIMARY: Look for data in the specified location/table/section
  2. FALLBACK: If not found, search broader document context for semantically equivalent information
  3. FLEXIBILITY: Allow for format variations, OCR errors, and synonym usage

  LOCATION FLEXIBILITY:
  - Handle table format variations (column/row order, spacing, naming)
  - Consider synonyms and equivalent terms
  - Account for OCR/parsing errors that may affect document quality

  QUALITY STANDARDS:
  - Extract actual values found in the document
  - If uncertain, provide best interpretation with appropriate confidence
  - Only return null if the information category truly doesn't exist
  - Convert abbreviated amounts (k=1000) to full numbers where applicable
  

  REPORT OUTPUT FOCUS:
  - 15 standard output categories in "List of Outputs" table
  - Each category: quantity number, descriptions list, URLs list
  - Separate descriptions from URLs even when mixed in same cell
  - Academic collaborations vs Industrial partnerships (distinct categories)
  - Preserve all detailed descriptions and web addresses
